section.title: can, can't, have to, don't have to
section.sectiontitle: We use can and can't + verb to talk about two different kinds possibility: ability and permission.
section.text1a: Sue can dance quite well but she can't sing.
section.sectiontitle2: In the question, we use can + subject + verb.
section.text4a: Can I park here? No, you can't.

section.title: <i>can, can't, have to, don't have to
section.sectiontitle: We use I/you/we/they + have to + verb or he/she/it + has to + verb if something is necessary.
section.text1: It's necessary for you to be at the airport by six o'clock.
section.text1a: You have to be at the airport by six o'clock.
section.text2: It's necessary for her to work very hard.
section.sectiontitle2: In the negative we use I/you/we/they + don't have to + verb or he/she/it + doesn't have to + verb if it's not necessary to do something.
section.text3: It isn't necessary for us to wear a uniform.
section.text3a: We don't have to wear a uniform.
section.text4: It isn't necessary for him to pay.
section.text4a: He doesn't have to pay. It's free for children.

section.title: <i>can, can't, have to, don't have to
section.sectiontitle: In the question, we use do + I/you/we/they + have to + verb or does + he/she/it + have to + verb.
section.text1a: Do you have to get up early? Yes, I do.
section.text2a: Does she have to speak English in her job? No, she doesn't.
